throughout the talk um but multi-platform app ui so it's it's a new uh workloading.net and it's a new uh
approach for for net developers to build ui apps and if you think about um what we
building.net at the moment in.net core or just.net.net5 what we're actually building is command line applications
even if it's a web server it's still a command line application it's just an executable that runs at the command line
that of course has changed now with blazer we can write blazer apps and their browser apps um but mali is a is
is a is a platform for writing ui apps so you can write amalia and that maui app will run on desktop or mobile uh on
any only any operating system really with some some caveats which again i'll cover later on
so that's what mao is uh now i'm going to talk about the history a little bit i'm going to go through this quite quickly even though
for me this is the most interesting part of the talk uh i i know you guys much more interested in seeing some code and
some demos so i'll go through this quickly um but the the multi-platform cross-platform dream started in 1996
with java and the reason this is important is because uh java was based on the philosophy of right once run anywhere
and uh before java uh ui application developers would write
their software to run against apis that were provided by the operating system so if you wanted to write a windows app you
had to use windows apis if you wanted to write a mac os app and you would write
using the mac apis and so on for other platforms as well java came along and said
don't do that and sorry by the way this isn't just for ui this is for anything any application that you wanted to write for these platforms uh you would have to
use the apis you would you would code against the apis provided by the the operating system java came along said
don't do that we're going to create a language which they did called java but more importantly a runtime so when
you're writing a java application you're writing uh code against the java apis
with the java runtime that runs your application not the operating system and you can install that java runtime on mac
os on linux on windows and you'd be able to write a java application that you could write once and run anywhere
so microsoft uh wanted a piece of this action and they dabbled with java a little bit as well but what they came up
with which got released eventually in 2002 was the net framework and by the way this isn't a comprehensive history
i'm just just calling out some highlights and so the net framework was similar to java in that you you had
languages that were developed for it that included c-sharp visual basic was ported to dot net um yeah we've had some
other languages along the way as well which i'm not going to talk too much about um but the point is you didn't write windows applications anymore you
wrote net applications.net framework applications and net framework provided a comprehensive set of apis and a base
class library that let you write applications against net not against windows
um that was 2002. um in 2004 mono came along and mono was
uh created by a couple of guys who at the time i believe were novell um and uh
and they created mono and mono is an open source implementation of net uh and so so now it's a net compile up and
runtime which was originally made for linux and it's now been ported to all kinds of platforms and underpins many of
the things that we use today including xamarin um unity uh blazer and i'll talk
a bit more about that later on uh mono eventually uh evolved via
something called monotouch which was an implementation for ios and mono droid which was an implementation for android
into xamarin um in fact xamarin android and xamarin.os and direct evolutions of monotouch and droid um and what what
they were specifically abstractions of the android and ios apis in.net so you
could write an android application or an ios application but you didn't have to use java or kotlin for android you
didn't have to use swift or objective c for for ios you could use c sharp or net um you're still writing ios and android
applications and this eventually involved into xamarin forms and xamarin forms let you write a ui as well so you
no longer had to write an ios or an android application um you could just write xamarin forms app and it would run
on those platforms again with some caveats and the experience wasn't 100 smooth you still really needed to be an
ios developer or an android developer and you could just take that net abstraction and do it
um moving ahead 2014 the.net foundation was created so dotnet is no longer just this
framework and this api and the spaceclass library it's an open standard so the dotnet foundation was created as
a not-for-profit to oversee uh net in the development of net as a standard as
a platform as a set of languages and as a set of related uh libraries and as we've seen recently that always works
really smoothly with no problems whatsoever and it's all sunshine and a fun ride for everyone
and the next big development in this journey was 2016 and this was.net core
so net framework uh had some limitations compared to java for example
uh one of those limitations is that it was windows only and so dotnet framework used you had to install it but you could
only install it in windows so you couldn't run uh net apps on other platforms without using something like mono and net core
came along and dotnet changed that so doc and change that net core is cross platform dot net core
runs on windows it runs on linux it runs on mac os it runs in you know pretty much every cloud
aws azure of course and many other clouds as well
um and the other uh cool thing about.net core is that it's a truly portable runtime so you can actually ship.net
core with your application uh and you can have it just execute your application and run it without it you know you can run it anywhere
um that was a big step another big step in 2016 was that
xamarin was acquired by microsoft so xamarin became a part of microsoft in 2016. that's an important step on this
journey um and then the next exciting thing is uh blazer so blazer let you run uh net
code in the browser we've kind of had this before with silverlight silverlight was awesome silverlight let you run wpf
code in your browser the problem with silverlight was that it was a plug-in and the world has moved on from
executing code uh in plugins and browser and the same thing happened with java you have java plug-ins that let you run
java applications in your browser but we've moved on from plugins and we've moved on to single page applications and
frameworks like uh you know react and angular as well as many others
so blazer is now via the magic of webassembly actually
lets you execute your dot net code in a browser without a plugin and so we can now write net
browser-based applications that was 2018. um and then of course the next big step
was last year and this was.net five so we got rid of the core um
you can see we've got the dot net bot as the mascot here um but the real the real important thing about dot net five which
we will look at in a moment is is that it's it's the journey towards one.net so even with net core
there's still a little bit fragmentation in the ecosystem we've got different different things that run and i've
developed and evolved independently dot five really started to bring that together
and of course the big one for our story here is dotnetmaui.net maui was originally uh scheduled to ship with dot
net six this month uh unfortunately it's not ready uh and it's it's really encouraging to see the
team pushing back and saying we're not gonna ship this yet it's not ready so um dotnet maui will be out next year
and we can see here that we've gone from this dream with java to write once run anywhere to the reality of that with
with.net maui that's coming next year that in a nutshell is the history of how we got here
so you've heard me mention xamarin a couple of times and some of you may know xamarin um i'd be interested to know how
many of you are xamarin developers and and how many of you are experimenting with maui um maui is is something new
it's born out of the dna of xamarin um but really it's a new thing it's as i
said it's really this opportunity for for net developers to embrace the fact that they can build ui applications and
and that's really what maui is it's got some roots in xamarin but it's a new thing and i'm going to talk about some of the differences here
uh one of them is the paradigm okay and xamarin is very much a bottom-up
paradigm i spoke briefly about this before what i mean by that is that the xamarin is born out of this idea that if
you know how to create an android app and you out or you know how to create an ios app you can
actually put some abstractions on top of that and you can do that in dot net still building an android app still
building an ios app still have to know the android apis and the ios apis but
you can abstract those out and use them in in.net and it's bottom up but you can build this ui layer across the top of it
with xamarin forms but it's still it's still bottom up with maui
it's top down and again i'm talking about the paradigm here and you know the engineering behind it it you know
obviously the difference is subtle but it's the paradigm and the idea with maui is that you build a maui app you're not
building a windows app you're not building a mac os app you're not building um you know an android or an
ios app what you're doing is you are building a maui app and that maui app can run anywhere
uh some of the architecture of how you built the xamarin app with um
with xamarin it was multiple projects so you would have your your core shared code project in your solution and that
would include things like services view models any kind of logic and your ui as well and xamarin forms but then you
would have an ios project which is what you would choose as your startup project if you want it to run on ios or target
ios for build the same thing for android with maui you've got a single project
it's just one project there's some spaces in there where you can do any kind of ios or android or
windows or mac specific logic that you want to but it's all still in the same project and you just choose a build target we'll have a look at how you do
that a little a little bit later on but it's one project where everything's just in the one project this makes things much easier
uh so xamarin is mobile focused so with xamarin you can build applications for windows you can build applications for
mac but but at its part it's about building mobile apps for ios and android
whereas with with maui as i said it's just it's maui first if you build a maui app and that maui can be run on all
these different platforms but you're building you're just building a ui application and that's that's really you know what
what the difference is there with xamarin i mentioned earlier about
the fragmentation in dot net and with dot net core how he had uh you know uh uh
you know the different parts of the dot net ecosystem that kind of evolved and were developed independently um and and
that was the case with xamarin it was it was not part of net it was it was an additional thing
that you installed uh and you could use to create uh xamarin applications with maui maui is a part of dotnet and we'll
we'll we'll see uh a bit about what difference that makes and how that's cool um but yeah and i think this is for

um the design pattern is is uh well so in xamarin uh you would use the mvvm
design pattern so this is model view view model and this is a design pattern that was
created for wpf and it has been brought forward into
into xamarin as well now you can use other
design patterns like mvu and you can do that in maui as well in xamarin it was it was community supported community
provided and via a couple of a couple of open source libraries in maui that's actually still the case
however maui is treating those as first-class citizens and you know as as maui develops you know we may see some
convergence there but the point is that the mvu is considered a first-class citizen in maui just like mvvm is

reload and as i mentioned earlier this is a nice part of of the dot net

abstraction called eye notification service if he's running on windows he wants to register this implementation for the
trade service this implementation for the notification service if he's on mac he wants to register this implementation
for the trade service and this implementation the notification service if he is on uh another platform he
doesn't want to register any implementation of that service at all because they're not they don't make sense a tray service doesn't make sense
um but as you can see rather than using logic at runtime to determine what platform you're on he's using a compiler
directive here the reason that i think that's interesting is that i have a real world
